keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after threats to 'shoot it up' were reported by his family.
Cagle was not armed at the time of arrest but an AR-15 assault rifle was found in his vehicle outside the airport.

He faces multiple charges including terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assaults, possession of a firearm in commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.
Cagle previously had a marijuana possession conviction over 20 years ago and is considered a convicted felon.
The airport, the world’s busiest, saw the incident as a near-tragedy due to high foot traffic and the potential for mass harm.
Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens emphasized the mental health and weapon combination risks involved.
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem expressed gratitude that no one was harmed.
Cartersville police were alerted by Cagle’s family, who reported he was armed and on his way to the airport.
Cagle was already at the airport, having arrived shortly before 9:30 a.m. at the south terminal.
The FBI is assisting in the investigation.
The incident underscores the importance of community vigilance and mental health awareness in public safety.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man named Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, the world’s busiest airport, after his family reported that he was armed and planning to 'shoot it up.' Though not armed at the time of arrest, police found an AR-15 assault rifle in his vehicle. Cagle, a convicted felon with a prior marijuana possession conviction, faces multiple charges, including terroristic threats and unlawful firearm possession. Authorities learned he had already arrived at the airport shortly before 9:30 a.m., where he was observed near the heavily crowded TSA check-in area. The incident was described as a 'tragedy averted' by Atlanta Police Chief Darin Schierbaum, with the FBI assisting in the investigation. Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens highlighted the danger of combining mental health challenges with access to firearms. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem praised the timely intervention, emphasizing that the arrest prevented potential mass harm. This event underscores the importance of community vigilance, mental health awareness, and airport security in preventing public safety threats.
title: Man arrested inside Atlanta airport after making threats to ‘shoot it up’
